Expectation1: Participate in project planning and provide accurate time estimates
Situation1: The planning session is informal, and the timeline can still shift without major impact
Expectation2: Live according to Christian moral values and ethics
Situation2: They face a serious situation that directly tests their commitment to Christian morals
Story:
I sat in the conference room, laptop open, as my project manager sketched out the new timeline on the whiteboard. The planning session was casual, and everyone knew the dates could shift if needed. Still, I was expected to give my best estimate for how long my part would take. As the discussion circled back to me, my manager leaned in and quietly suggested, “If you can shave a week off your estimate, it’ll make us look good to the client. We can always adjust later.” I knew the numbers he wanted weren’t realistic, but the pressure to comply was strong.

At that moment, my mind raced. As an engineer, I was supposed to be practical and flexible, especially since the timeline wasn’t set in stone. But as a Christian, honesty and integrity were non-negotiable. I felt the weight of both roles pressing in—one urging me to play along for the team’s benefit, the other reminding me that my word should be truthful, even in small things. My heart pounded as I stared at the numbers on my screen, caught between loyalty to my team and loyalty to my faith, unsure which voice to follow.
